question.title: GLSurfaceView causing ANR after activity is destroyed

node.contents: I have an Activity containing a GLSurfaceView. When I hit the back button to go the previous Activity, it manages to show that Activity, but the screen is then unresponsive and will eventually ANR.

astNode.text: I have an Activity containing a GLSurfaceView. When I hit the back button to go the previous Activity, it manages to show that Activity, but the screen is then unresponsive and will eventually ANR.

node.contents: If I move the mSurfaceView.onPause(); to the owner fragment's onPause() then the app does not freeze after backing out of the fragment, but it will usually crash silently (no force close) a few seconds after backing out of the fragment.

astNode.text: If I move the mSurfaceView.onPause(); to the owner fragment's onPause() then the app does not freeze after backing out of the fragment, but it will usually crash silently (no force close) a few seconds after backing out of the fragment.

elements.contents: @Override public void onSurfaceCreated(GL10 gl, EGLConfig config) { if (mOpenGlesVersion == OPENGLES_VERSION_10) mOpenGles = new OpenGles10(); else if (mOpenGlesVersion == OPENGLES_VERSION_11) mOpenGles = new OpenGles11(); else if (mOpenGlesVersion == OPENGLES_VERSION_20) mOpenGles = new OpenGles20(); // Let the caller know the surface has been created. if (mListener != null) mListener.onGLSurfaceViewCreated(); // No intention of drawing anything, just gathering info. mSurfaceView.onPause(); }

comments.text: // Let the caller know the surface has been created. if (mListener != null) mListener.onGLSurfaceViewCreated(); // No intention of drawing anything, just gathering info. mSurfaceView.onPause(); }

node.contents: Your Graphics.onSurfaceCreated() invoked GLSurfaceView.onPause(). You should not invoke onPause or you meet a dead lock. onPause() will invoke wait() and your surfaceDestroyed() will invoke wait().

astNode.text: Your Graphics.onSurfaceCreated() invoked GLSurfaceView.onPause(). You should not invoke onPause or you meet a dead lock. onPause() will invoke wait() and your surfaceDestroyed() will invoke wait().

node.contents: This is a known bug in GLSurfaceView. This is due to having more than a single live GLSurfaceView in your app. I've tried the suggested fix (look at the previous link), but ended having to redesign my app to dispose GLSurfaceView instances manually.

astNode.text: This is a known bug in GLSurfaceView. This is due to having more than a single live GLSurfaceView in your app. I've tried the suggested fix (look at the previous link), but ended having to redesign my app to dispose GLSurfaceView instances manually.

node.contents: My trick was to call removeView() on the GLSurfaceView's parent, thus causing its םnDetachedAFromView() event to be fired.

astNode.text: My trick was to call removeView() on the GLSurfaceView's parent, thus causing its םnDetachedAFromView() event to be fired.

node.contents: This is less than optimal, but that's life.

astNode.text: This is less than optimal, but that's life.

node.contents: (B.T.W. a refrence for future Googlers - in my app the culprit was ArcGIS's MapView).

astNode.text: (B.T.W. a refrence for future Googlers - in my app the culprit was ArcGIS's MapView).
